Award.AwardTitle: Virginia Teach, Phase II: A Community-Based Approach to Serving Mathematics Students in Need

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The intellectual merit of this Phase II Noyce project builds on the success of a previous project, which supported 30 Noyce scholars, with some now entering their fourth year of professional teaching. This Phase II project is supporting an additional 25 talented students who are training to become secondary mathematics teachers in high-need school districts. The Virginia Teach project expands the number of school district partnerships to better serve high-need schools in both urban and rural districts. New partnerships with local community colleges are supporting this goal by helping the project recruit scholars from the high-need districts in which they may serve. In addition to the scholarship support that this project provides, it also fosters vibrant clusters of field experience and professional teaching placements with ongoing support for these professional communities. The project is continuing to monitor and evaluate Phase I scholars as well as those being added in Phase II, providing longitudinal data on the preparation and success of scholars as they enter professional teaching. Thus, Virginia Teach is conducting research that contributes to the knowledge base related to recruiting and training teachers to work with students in high-need districts. Accordingly, this project is answering questions such as, "What elements of mathematics certification programs best support undergraduates' transitions from students to teachers?"

Besides providing well-prepared math teachers for high-need school districts, the intellectual merit of this project also derives from the newly forged partnerships with school districts and community colleges. Such partnerships have resulted in a new, collaborative student project focused on how to best serve ESL mathematics students. Further, the partnerships with local school districts have broader impacts through permanently improving the certification program at Virginia Tech. The partnerships with local community colleges are expected to lead to permanent recruitment pipelines. Finally, presentations at mathematics teacher conferences and publications in peer-reviewed journals are planned in order to disseminate lessons learned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Virginia Teach, Phase II: A Community-Based Approach to Serving Mathematics Students in Need, was a Noyce grant primarily focused on increasing the number of highly qualified mathematics teachers in high needs schools. Our focus was on doing this through the recruitment of STEM majors from Virginia Tech and partnering community colleges into our mathematics education program, resulting in licensure to teach in the Commonwealth of Virginia. In addition, we were interested in seeing how the concept of community could be used to increase placement and retention of highly qualified mathematics teachers in targeted high needs schools. 

We planned to use community in three ways: First, we planned to continue to support the professional community of Virginia Teach Noyce alumni who were supported by either Phase I or Phase II of the grant. Second, we planned to create clusters of student teachers and cooperating teachers in both urban and rural high needs schools in partnering school districts. Third, we planned to recruit students from high poverty communities through our community college partners in order to increase the likelihood of our alumni staying at high needs schools in these communities after they had completed the obligatory 2 years of teaching per year of scholarship or stipend they received through the grant.

We were successful in recruiting and preparing highly qualified secondary mathematics teachers. In all, we recruited 29 students. At the end of the grant period, 2 had decided not to teach and did not complete the licensure program, 4 were still completing the licensure program, and 23 have taught or are contracted to teach in high needs schools. During Scholars’ tenure at Virginia Tech, we met 2-3 times a year for networking, questions about the program and employment searches, and to plan presentations for the Virginia Council of Teachers of Mathematics annual conferences. Furthermore, we continued to support a professional community among both these Scholars and Scholars from Phase I of the grant through yearly meetings at the Virginia Council of Teachers of Mathematics Annual Meetings or the regional meeting of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics. In addition, our program evaluator(s) attempted to keep in touch with, meet with, and observe all Scholars from both Phase I and II of the grant, as was possible. During the final year we had a no-cost extension and PI Ulrich continued the contact and observations with Scholars who were still completing their teaching obligation. Of the 23 students we recruited in Phase II who received licensure, 22, or 95.7% are currently teaching or contracted to teach in high needs schools. The program evaluator worked with additional Scholars from Phase I of the Virginia Teach grant. She reports: "39 of the 42 Noyce students who graduated prior to 2017, were still teaching in 2016-2017. This is an almost 93% retention rate."

We were able to form clusters of students at one of the rural schools in a partnering school district each year and at one of the urban schools in a different partnering school district 5 of the 6 years. We do not have any evidence that the cooperating teachers at these schools worked any more closely due to these clusters. However, these placements in our partnering school districts was effective in encouraging Noyce Scholars and other Virginia Tech alumni to work in these school districts and resulted in both school districts offering early contracts to our students by the end of the grant period. Five of the 23 Scholars were hired by one of our partnering school districts and four are still in those school districts.

Despite three recruiting trips and multiple emails to our partners at area community colleges, we were not successful in recruiting any community college graduates to accept 3-year scholarships. Based on conversations with our community college contacts, we believe that part of the problem was the lack of an established pipeline from the community colleges to the Mathematics Department at Virginia Tech. In particular, students and advisors were unclear on what courses would transfer and therefore whether the community college students would reasonably be able to complete a major in Mathematics within two years of transferring. PI Ulrich and co-PI Norton worked together to create a clear indication of which community college courses would fulfill requirements for the Mathematics (Education option) major. That document is used in recruiting and communications with community colleges throughout Virginia.

We disseminated information about lessons learned and best practices through posters and a breakout session at the annual Noyce Summits in Washington, DC; and posters and sessions/workshops at the Southeast Noyce Conferences.
